column4: Right now I'd love to know why I can't put anything into my ~/.Xsession ...
But I would have expected to find something in the network configuration program in the Gnome panel.
When I didn't find it there, I sighed and fetched a few HOWTOs from tldp.org.
I think that Ubuntu should put it into a more prominent place.  DSL over PPP is quite common these days.
I want to shadow the path for the Gnome panels, application launchers etc., too.
While I am at it: I have another minor quirk (which I already solved):
I understand why they "disable" root. But instead they should just give it the same password as the default user.
I did something wrong with my network stuff when installing. So that the name I gave to my computer was not resolved to 127.0.0.1
This had the effect that Gnome did not work properly:  I could not get a root shell, for instance.
So I had to reboot in the "protected mode" in order to fix my problem.
I do.  But I missed that I can use it with my normal password.  Besides that I am not sure anymore whether I was able to get a terminal at all.
Sure you could.  Applications -> System Tools -> Root Terminal.
Like other things that require root, it prompts you for your password.
Intriguing, I haven't heard of a bug like that before.  I don't suppose you know enough details to reproduce it and/or file a bug report?
Did it give you any error messages?
only when logging in: that Gnome could not resolve the name I gave to my machine. (That problem is already fixed.)
What about running sudo from the command line?
